Headline.Para: Who Makes Oprah Winfrey's Favorite Fried Chicken? That's a Bone of Contention; Two Seattle-area restaurants battle over her endorsement; 'some pretty darn good chicken'

LeadPara.Para: SEATTLEâ€”Inside Ezell's Famous Chicken in Seattle's Central District neighborhood, there is the unmistakable smell of fried breading, and an endorsement from Oprah Winfrey.

"Ezell's, I don't know what I like more, the chicken or the sweet potato pie!" Ms. Winfrey wrote on a framed studio photograph of herself displayed next to the cash register. "Thank you. It was something special."

TailParas.Para: Missing from Ezell's: Ezell.
Ezell Stephens, the co-founder of Ezell's, left after a falling out with partners who started the business with him, and opened his own chain of competing chicken restaurants.
Nearly 30 years after her review, Ms. Winfrey's bite of fried chicken has launched a drumstick war separating Seattle into fowl factions.
"Their chicken is called Ezell's," said Mr. Stephens. "It's not Ezell's. Hell, it was only Ezell's when Ezell was there."
Mr. Stephens' restaurant, Heaven Sent Fried Chicken, declares itself "Oprah's Favorite Fried Chicken" on its website.
Not so fast, says Lewis Rudd, president of Ezell's Famous Chicken. He says Ezell's uses the same recipes today as it did when it won raves from Ms. Winfrey.
Mr. Rudd said that he delivered chicken to Ms. Winfrey on multiple occasions, and met her in Chicago in 1990.
Mr. Rudd wouldn't comment on Mr. Stephens' split with the company.
Ms. Winfrey said she still remembers her meals after all these years.

"That was some pretty darn good chicken and I'd love to see a runoff between them (Heaven Sent, Ezell's) and Art Smith," she said in a statement, referring to her former personal chef, "who has been making peace around the world with his fried chicken."
Seattle residents host impromptu taste tests and pick favoritesâ€”by dish. Some prefer Heaven Sent chicken, but Ezell rolls.

"If they sided with Ezell's Famous Chicken, the taster could present themselves as loyalists and patriots," wrote reviewer Hanna Raskin in Seattle Weekly. "But aligning themselves with the bird from Heaven Sent...would make them certifiable fans of the underdogâ€”and, perhaps, discerning connoisseurs of chicken genius."
Seattle's chicken saga started peacefully. Mr. Rudd says he founded the restaurant with Mr. Stephens and other friends and family members in 1984.

On a visit to Seattle five years later, Ms. Winfrey asked where she could get some good fried chicken and was pointed toward Ezell's. She liked it so much she ordered it two days in a row and talked it up on her show, according to Mr. Stephens. Later, Mr. Stephens said he was hired to cook for her birthday party in Chicago.
Several years after he cooked for Ms. Winfrey, Mr. Stephens started two restaurants also called Ezell's Famous Chicken, separate from the original company.
The company sued, and Mr. Stephens changed the name of his restaurants to Heaven Sent.
Ezell's Famous Chicken has grown to 13 locations, not including food trucks. Heaven Sent has three locations.
Both restaurants offer much the same fare: spicy and regular pieces of fried chicken; classic sides such as mashed potatoes and gravy and coleslaw; chicken tenders; and, of course, sweet potato pie.
To this day, both companies continue to celebrate the decades-old endorsement from Ms. Winfrey.

Mr. Stephens points out he's the person who cooked for Ms. Winfrey on her birthday in 1990, a fact he's traded on heavily since he founded Heaven Sent. It's a central part of his story on his website. On Facebook the company declares "you will only find Ezell Stephens, the person who cooked for Oprah at Heaven Sent Fried Chicken." Through the years, he has included that in commercials.

He opens one commercial by introducing himself: "Hi, I'm Ezell Stephens, owner of Heaven Sent Fried Chicken. The name's changed, but it's still me that's making the world's best fried chicken. Now that's the same fried chicken that Oprah flew me to Chicago to make for her birthday."
He ends it with: "Come on in, take a picture with me. Oprah did."
Says Mr. Stephens, "When you say Oprah liked it, I mean, what else you need to know? She can have anything she wants."

Ms. Winfrey, who has long espoused a healthy lifestyleâ€”though not a deprived oneâ€”is a Weight Watchers board member and investor. The Weight Watchers website has Southern-Style Oven-Fried Chicken on a list of 30 most popular recipes.

Waiting to pick up an order of chicken tenders at Heaven Sent's Lake City location, Brian Besley said he was introduced to Ezell's about a decade ago when a friend told him it was Ms. Winfrey's favorite fried chicken. But, he says: "I really don't care what Oprah thinks." He says the chicken more or less tastes the same at both restaurants, but he prefers the rolls at Ezell's.
That could be because Mr. Stephens changed the recipeâ€”though he wouldn't say how much.
Mr. Stephens says he "tweaked everything" when he opened Heaven Sent. "I made it mine," he says. "I'm Ezell. I make sure you can taste that."
Ms. Winfrey, in her statement, also praised another cook, a relative of her longtime partner, Stedman Graham: "The other amazing chicken is made by Stedman's cousin Durkie in his own backyard!"
